docs.lead_paragraph: There is probably no better vantage point on the changes creeping across this oil-drenched sultanate than astride one of the sleek, powerful horses at the Jerudong Park Polo Club. Not long ago, the club's 200 imported Argentine ponies, immaculate fields and opulent clubhouse were restricted to family and guests of Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah. Now, in what this country has declared Visit Brunei Year, anyone can ride for as little as $20.

headline.main: How to Say No To a Sultan; Brunei and Its Leader Try Economic Discipline

docs.abstract: Sultan Hassanal Bolkiash of Brunei, whose lavish spending helped push country into recession, now acts as economic disciplinarian, trying to less its dependence on oil production and into global economy; Brunei has been vowing to diversify its economy since mid-1980's, but reductions in dominance of oil have been achieved largely by raising government outlays; surging oil prices have taken some urgency out of reform drive; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration's program to direct more federal funds to church-run social welfare programs seemed like a good idea for at least five minutes. But now it's taking fire from all sides -- Christian conservatives, libertarians and some mainline Catholic and Jewish organizations that are comfortable with the rules the way they are. This shouldn't surprise anyone. Those of us who live in New York can tell you how many problems arise when church and state start drifting together. This is the place where parking regulations turn into faith-based initiatives.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column on Bush administration's program to direct more federal funds to church-run social welfare programs says it may have seemed like good idea for short time, but is beginning to take fire from all sides; says situation should come as no surprise because of myriad problems that can arise when church and state start drifting together (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration's program to direct more federal funds to church-run social welfare programs seemed like a good idea for at least five minutes. But now it's taking fire from all sides -- Christian conservatives, libertarians and some mainline...

docs.lead_paragraph: During the presidential campaign last year, former President George Bush took time off from his son's race to call on Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia at a luxurious desert compound outside Riyadh to talk about American-Saudi business affairs. Mr. Bush went as an ambassador of sorts, but not for his government. In the same way, Mr. Bush's secretary of state, James A. Baker III, recently met with a group of wealthy people at the elegant Lanesborough Hotel in London to explain the Florida vote count.

headline.main: Elder Bush in Big G.O.P. Cast Toiling for Top Equity Firm

docs.abstract: Former Pres George Bush and former secretary of state James A Baker III are using extensive government contacts to further business interests as representatives of Carlyle Group; $12 billion private equity firm based in Washington has parlayed roster of former top-level government officials, largely from Bush and Reagan administrations, into money-making machine; in new spin on Washington's revolving door between business and government, where lobbying by foreign officials is restricted but soliciting investments is not, company has upped ante by taking practice global; Bush and Baker have been accompanied by former British Prime Min John Major, helping transform Carlyle from unknown in world of private equity to one of its biggest players; photos (M)
docs.snippet: During the presidential campaign last year, former President George Bush took time off from his son's race to call on Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia at a luxurious desert compound outside Riyadh to talk about American-Saudi business affairs.  ...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''A Handyman Is Shot at Work, or Was He?'' (Workplace section, Feb. 28) underscored the sheer lunacy of the workers' compensation system. What difference does it make whether an employee is disabled on or off the job? The person can no longer work and earn money. The workers' compensation program actually fosters lying in order to collect benefits.
docs.abstract: Thomas Kagan letter says Feb 28 article underscores sheer lunacy of workers' compensation system; says all companies should be required to provide health and disability insurance to all workers

docs.lead_paragraph: WALTER SALDARRIAGA never expected to get any help from a union. Like many of the poor Hispanic immigrants in Westchester and Putnam Counties, he spent more than a decade working 12-hour days as a dishwasher with no benefits and no vacations, earning just enough to support his wife and two children in a cramped, run-down apartment.
docs.abstract: Article on outreach program initiated by Sheet Metal Workers Local 38, to train unskilled and underpaid immigrant day laborers as highly-paid apprentice metal workers with full package of benefits; class in Brewster, NY, is first of its kind in region and represents significant new direction for union and immigrant laborers; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST month in this space, there was a mention of a woman who complained in an Internet chat room about fighting with her insurance company over paying for anesthesia she had received when she had a Caesarean section. But anesthesia deserves more than a throwaway line, because if you give birth or have any type of surgery, anesthesia bills may well show up in your mailbox. (Proponents of natural childbirth need not write to comment about the joys of drug-free birth; this is an insurance issue.) It comes back to a very important question: What does 100 percent hospitalization coverage actually buy? You certainly get on-staff attending doctors, medical residents, nurses, drugs, your room and the use of the operating room, not to mention those cool socks with the treads on the bottom. Often not included, however, are doctors from outside the hospital.

headline.main: Telling Dr. Inside From Dr. Outside

docs.abstract: People should make sure that anesthesiologists and other doctors that may treat them during hospital stay are covered by their plans; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the suburbs you hear a lot of droning noises. Lawn mowers and leaf blowers dominate their respective seasons. Then there is the hum of traffic on the major arteries. Lately in my town, we have gotten very used to hearing the loud drone of chain saws as a number of aging and ailing trees are taken down. This is usually followed by the distinctive roar of a chipper shredder turning those trees into wood chips.

headline.main: Give Your Naked Trees a Good Once-Over

docs.abstract: Elisabeth Ginsburg In the Garden column notes late winter is good time for suburban homeowners to closely examine trees devoid of leaves for disease or damage; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I probably shouldn't be telling you this. But I can't keep quiet now, not after hearing Francis Collins sing. The director of the National Human Genome Research Institute was onstage with his band, the Directors, celebrating the sequencing of the human genome. The band plays oldies refitted with gene-related lyrics. Nerdy good fun, right? Then they got to Del Shannon's ''Runaway,'' sung from the perspective of one anonymous donor whose DNA was sequenced. ''I'm a walkin' through the genes/Don't know what all this means/No one else knows that it's me/Behind that G and T.'' I swear Collins was staring right at me as he sang, ''And I wonder, wo-wo-wo-wo-wonder.'' Busted. Well, almost. I am wondering about the other genome sequence, the one published by Collins's private-sector rival J. Craig Venter and his Celera Genomics. I can't be certain that I am one of the Celera Five, the group whose DNA makes up their genome sequence, but there's a good chance. Along with 20 other men and women from a variety of ethnic backgrounds, I gave Venter my DNA last year to do whatever he wanted with it.
docs.abstract: Thomas Hayden Lives article on donating DNA that might have been sequenced by Craig Venter and his Celera Genomics; cites feeling of exposure as modern biology reveals that all humans are mutants; notes possibly being first scrutinized also makes him standard for all future comparison (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS President Bush sent his budget blueprint to Capitol Hill last week, he offered an exquisitely calibrated view of government that seemed just slightly to the right of President Clinton's ''third way'': ''Government should be active, but limited, engaged, but not overbearing.'' Just the right size for a public that consistently shows mistrust of ''government'' but strong support for individual government programs. A careful middle ground. Then why are so many conservatives so happy -- and liberals so despairing? Because, both sides believe, Mr. Bush's neo-Clintonian formulations mask a major shift in the vision of government and a new stage in a philosophic debate that has raged across two generations. Mr. Bush's proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut, combined with his leaner budget and his proposals to remake Social Security and Medicare, could begin to turn the battleship of the federal government in a direction conservative Republicans have wanted for a long time.

headline.main: The World: Capitalist Tools; Cutting a Rightward Path

docs.abstract: Comment on conservatives' happiness with Pres Bush's agenda, and liberals' fear that his neo-Clintonian formulations, while seeming just slightly to the right, would in fact revive and retrofit Reagan era by curbing spending and ceding more resonsibilities to state and local governments and religious institutions (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AROUND our house, there were two big stories in the footwear business recently: Critics of Nike again walked all over the company because of conditions in Indonesian factories. And my son got new sneakers for $7. Is there a connection between the two events? You bet. They both involve third-world workers desperate to better themselves. The difference is that, by buying the $7 sneakers, we actually did some good.

headline.main: Nike in Indonesia, Through a Different Lens

docs.abstract: Daniel Akst column says Nike, which is loudly criticized on working conditions in its snearker factories in third world, is actually running one of world's most extensive international development programs; says knock-off sneakers that consumers might turn to as result of the anti-Nike campaign are probably made under worse conditions; cartoon (M)
